quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Guns and World War
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, turbojet, world. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Even though mainland Britain was not actually invaded in World War II, it had prepared a resistance movement, known under what name?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Auxiliary Units

questions.question: Six gigantic guns were created during World War II, with the help of general Karl Baker. They were called Karl Monsers and were used in the Brest-Litovsk and Warsaw uprisings. What was their other deployment during the War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The siege of Sevastopol

questions.question: One of the most accomplished ballistics engineers, Gerald Bull, was head of project HARP. The Pentagon and the Canadian Department of National Defence joined efforts in this project, trying to study ballistics of re-entry vehicles at low cost. They used 16 inch (406 mm) 50 caliber gun, which was later extended to 100 calibers (40 m), to fire shells toward the Atlantic at 3600 m/s. Do you know what HARP stood for?

options.text: Helping to Attract and Recruit Project

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: High Altitude Research Project

questions.question: The Tripartite Pact was signed on September 27, 1940 by Germany, Italy and Japan. Later, three more countries joined - Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria. When did Bulgaria join the pact?
Which plane was the first operational turbojet to take part in WW II?
Who accepted the surrender of the German military forces in Northwest Germany, Holland and Denmark on May 4, 1945?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: General Montgomery

questions.question: During World War I Germany built and used one of the biggest guns in military history, Big Bertha. It fired 2,100 lb (820 kg) shells at a range of 15 km (9.3 miles) and was used in the assault of Verdun. Big Bertha was named after this member of the designers family.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: His wife

questions.question: Tsar Pushka, the biggest cannon of its time, was created in Russia in 1586 and was later used to defend the Kremlin.

This is the biggest gun ever to be completed. It was 43 m (141 feet) long, weighed 1350 tons and fired 7 ton shells at range of 40 km (25 miles). It was capable of piercing a meter (3.3 feet) of steel or 7 meters (23 feet) of concrete. One of the two ever built guns of this type was called Schwerer Gustav. What was the name of the other one?
Even though Bertha was a formidable gun, this one was even bigger. Paris Gun was used to bombard Paris during World War I. What was its main purpose?

options.text: To kill as many civilians as possible
To attack the morale of enemy soldiers

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: To attack the morale of enemy soldiers

questions.question: Before committing suicide, Adolf Hitler appointed his successors. Schwerin von Krosigk was one of them.
Lange Max (long Max) was a World War I German cannon officially called 38cm SKL/45.  Long Max was derived from the Paris Gun.
This May 1942 battle was the first one to be fought only by aircraft carriers.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Battle of the Coral Sea

questions.question: Two of the German K5(E) guns were called Anzio Annes, because they shelled the coast of Anzio during WW II.

During World War I and II, this German family created some of the biggest guns in the world. In the years of WW I they sold cannons to the the Entente as well as the Central Powers. Their work became the center for German rearmament after 1933 (when Hitler came to power).

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Movie and Vietnam
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, actor, john. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: In what year did the popular sitcom, Friends, first air?
Who directed the 1986 movie Platoon?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Oliver Stone

questions.question: This actor, who starred in the movie Good Morning, Vietnam, also acted in the TV series Walker: Texas Ranger.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Noble Willingham

questions.question: This independent horror film tells the story of 3 student filmmakers who get lost in the woods and are tormented by a legend witch.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Blair Witch Project

questions.question: On August 12 of this year, the Major League Baseball players went on strike which resulted in the cancellation of the World Series.
This 1978 movie was about a group of American soldiers who went to fight in Vietnam. They could get out of combat if they threw a soccer match, but they refused to do so.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Boys in Company C

questions.question: John Gray wrote the popular book Men Are From Mars, Women Are From Venus.
Which movie star was featured in the only movie about the Vietnam War that was made during the war?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Wayne

questions.question: The  main actors in Platoon had to go through a 14-day military boot camp.
The 1990s introduced us all to grunge music. Which popular grunge band are known for their 1994 song Black Hole Sun?
Which Vietnam movie featured Tom Cruise, Tom Berenger and Willem Dafoe?

options.text: Born on the Fourth of July

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Born on the Fourth of July

questions.question: This Hollywood veteran played Sgt. Muldoon in a 1968 movie about the war in Vietnam.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Aldo Ray

questions.question: On what cartoon from the 90s did we meet the characters Tommy, Angelica, and Chuckie?

Gerald Bull took part in another supergun program - project Babylon. He supplied the plans for a series of gigantic guns, but fortunately only one of them (the smallest one) was completed. This person commissioned the project.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Saddam Hussein

questions.question: Who directed the 1989 movie Casualties of War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Brian DePalma

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: October and Fire
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, john, conclave. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The Orient Express, a long-distance passenger train that has become a synonym with luxury travel, made its first run on October 4, 1883. This was the final destination of its first route.
Not only Jews were targeted by Hitler, but also the Gypsies and the mentally and physically disable.
On October 18, 1968,  a police raid on John Lennon and Yoko Onos apartment revealed 168 grams of marijuana. This is what happened to Lennon and Ono as a result.

options.text: The evidence mysteriously disappeared and the case was dismissed
They were found guilty and were sent to prison
They were found not guilty and released, due to Lennons great contribution to British music
They plead guilty and were fined £150

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They plead guilty and were fined £150

questions.question: On October 7, 1982,  this show made its debut in Broadway at the Winter Garden Theatre. It eventually closed after nearly 18 years on September 10, 2000.
Which of these movies did not feature R. Lee Ermey?
On October 11, 1968, NASA launched Apollo 7, the first manned Apollo mission.
This 1989 movie was about an injured Vietnam War veteran who became an anti-war protester.

options.text: Born on the Fourth of July

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Born on the Fourth of July

questions.question: Who directed the 1979 movie Apocalypse Now?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Francis Ford Coppola

questions.question: On October 16, 1978, the Papal Conclave elected Karol Józef Wojtyła, who became known as Pope John Paul II. How old was he when this happened?
Beginning with racially discriminatory laws in Germany, the Nazi campaign expanded to the mass murder of a great part of European Jews.

The Great Chicago Fire, one of the worst disasters of the nineteenth century, started on October 8, 1871. The fire destroyed approximately 17,450 buildings, killed 250 people and left another 90,000 homeless, before it was extinguished on this date.
For his role as Pvt. Pyle in Full Metal Jacket, Vincent DOnofrio, had to gain 70 pounds. This broke the previous record for weight gained by a featured actor for a role. Who had held this record?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Robert De Niro

questions.question: Holocaust is a Greek word, originally meaning sacrifice by fire.
Who directed the 1987 film Full Metal Jacket?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Stanley Kubrick

questions.question: What year did the Holocaust begin?

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Leader and People
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, leader, invention. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Although the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising wasnt successful, it was the first significant uprising in German-occupied Europe during WW II.
Which of the following was the first Roman emperor to convert to Christianity in 313 AD?
Which writer witnessed the eruption of Mt. Vesuvius in 79 AD?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pliny the Younger

questions.question: According to some theories, the parachute was invented in 1783 by Sebastien Lenormand in France. Two years later, Jean-Pierre Blanchard demonstrated it as a means of safely getting down on earth from this.
The armed uprising in the Warsaw ghetto in April-May 1943 was one of the most forceful Jewish uprising in the organized resistance to the Nazis.
Which Roman Emperor wrote The Meditations that was actually a sort of personal diary?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Marcus Aurelius

questions.question: Who is widely recognized as the leader of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising during WW II?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mordechai Anielewicz

questions.question: Who was the great Roman orator who created a Latin stylebook which is still used in Latin classes today?
During WW II, Polish-Jewish industrialist Chaim Rumkowski was the leader of the Lodz Ghetto.
The first military submarine (Turtle) could accommodate this number of people.
This invention (named by Edward Jenner) is not an object, but a process of administering live, albeit weakened, microbes to people.
In Ancient Rome, who were the Lares?

options.text: The elite corps of the Roman army
The Roman counterpart of the Greek Furies

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Household spirits of dead ancestors

questions.question: The optical telegraph (a collective term) preceded the electrical telegraph. It was much faster than riding couriers in to deliver messages over long distances. One of these is not an optical telegraph.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Morse code

questions.question: At the end of the Nazi rule, Hitler expressed his sincere regret for all the deaths he and his subordinates had caused during the Holocaust.
Which of these poets wrote many poems of love and manners widely read by Ancient Romans?

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Gold and Discovery
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, spinning, discovery. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The Colorado Gold Rush of 1859 was followed by a silver boom (a period of great silver mining).
The nickname of Wisconsin, “Badger State?, was given to it in irony, because no gold rushes occurred in the region.
Which one of these famous writers took part in the Klondike Gold Rush?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jack London

questions.question: One man who made a fortune out of gold rushes was Levi Strauss. He developed the concept of this.
What was Cleopatras ethnic background?
Most gold rushes began with the discovery of placer gold by a single man or a party of people. Which one of these statements about placer mining is wrong?

options.text: Placer mining is not used any more
Placer gold is mined without tunneling
Hydrostatic pressure is used whenever possible
Placer gold deposits are usually found near big rivers and mountain streams

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Placer mining is not used any more

questions.question: One of the earliest gold rushes was probably the Spanish search for the mythical city of El Dorado. According to early legends, the King of the Muiscas would do this as part of a religious ceremony.

options.text: Turn whatever he touches into gold

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cover himself with gold dust

questions.question: Charlie Chaplins movie The Gold Rush, which took in more than $4,250,000 at the box office in 1925, was set in his city.
Which of the following was NOT an Egyptian pharaoh?
The spinning jenny is a multi-spool spinning wheel invented in 1764 in this country.
Many people seeking an easy fortune emigrated to California, USA during the California Gold Rush (1848-1858). The gold rush was sparked by the discovery of gold near this city.
This technique for extracting gold was discovered by chemist Carl Wilhelm Scheele in 1783, and was later developed in 1887 by John Seward MacArthur.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gold cyanidation

questions.question: In 1807, Robert Fulton used a steam engine to power the first commercially successful one of these.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Steam ship

questions.question: Which was the first Egyptian pyramid?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Step Pyramid

questions.question: The San Francisco 49ers are an NFL team named after the prospectors that took part in the California Gold Rush.

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Date and Ancient Egypt
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, egypt, space. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which of the following was referred to as the Gift of the Nile?
This bagged vegetable was recalled on September 16, 2006 after E. coli affected people in 19 U. S. states.
On what date in September of 2006 did Steve Irwin the Crocodile Hunter die due to a stingray attack?
Incestuous royal marriages were common in Ancient Egypt.
Who was the last Tsar of Russia, King of Poland and Grand Duke of Finland?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nicholas II

questions.question: On October 19, 2006 Nissan Motor Company recalled 80,000 cars in U.S. due to what defects?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: in the ignition key

questions.question: Where is the Nile Delta located?

options.text: at the source of the river

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lower Egypt

questions.question: Who was the first king in history to foster a belief in one God?
On what day in July did the Space Shuttle Discovery touch down on Earth after a 13-day trip to the International Space Station?
Who was chosen to be the 2006 Time Magazines Person of the Year?
On October 9, 2006, this Internet company announced its purchase of the popular YouTube site?
On what date in August did the Israeli and Hezbolah conflict end with a ceasefire?
Who unified Upper and Lower Egypt?
Former Enron executive Kenneth Lay died of a heart attack at the age of 66 on July 5, 2006.
How many distinct kingdoms were there in Ancient Egypt?
